awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: L1 Biases in Learning Root-and-Pattern Morphology
awd_abstract_narration:
How does the knowledge of our first language affect our ability to learn other languages? This dissertation examines how the rules we already know help or hinder our efforts to learn rules in a new language. Semitic languages like Arabic and Maltese employ root-and-pattern morphology to form words. Unlike in English, where meaningful pieces of words are usually tacked onto the ends of words (dis-em-bowel-ment), Semitic languages tend to change the vowels in the middle of the words for the same effect (kitaab 'book' --> kutub 'books'). Though most of the previous research shows that learning how to correctly interweave consonants and vowels like this is very difficult for English speakers, recent research shows that this task is easier if you speak a language that uses similar rules. To carry out this research, an artificial language is created that mimics Arabic plural pairs like kitaab and kutub, and is taught to English speakers, students learning Arabic, Arabic speakers, and Maltese speakers.

This research uses two psycholinguistic methods to investigate the effects of linguistic biases on learning rules in new languages: a segmentation task and a Wug Test. The segmentation task allows for direct comparison to previous studies, and the Wug Test is more sensitive to how well participants have learned the artificial language. In the segmentation task, participants listen to a randomized string of nonsense words, then must select the words that they heard as well as possible words based on the rule that they were able to extrapolate. In the Wug Test, participants are briefly shown how to create the plural in an "alien language", then are asked to provide the plurals for each item following the rules that they learned. Participant groups were selected on the basis of their exposure to root-and-pattern morphology, as linguistic biases may depend on learning a language natively or may be developed while learning another language. This research has implications not only for theories of language acquisition and mental representation of morphology, but also for Arabic language pedagogy, especially for heritage learners.

por.por_cntn:
This project's aim was to investigate the effect of participants' native language on learning a new language. The particular focus of the project was to examine how word formation processes and abstract word structure expectations might be transferred from a participant's native language to a new language. For example, Arabic and Maltese have a word formation process called templatic morphology that requires speakers to interleave consonants and vowels to form new, related words (e.g., in Arabic, kitaab 'book', kutub 'books',kaatib 'writer', maktaba 'library'), as well as a process similar to English where additional word parts might be added to the beginnings and endings of words (e.g., 'writer -s', 'book -ing', 'chapter+book'). Since other aspects of a person's native language, such as word order in sentences and acceptable sequences of sounds, may be carried over to a new language, it is reasonable to assume that knowledge of word formation processes should also be carried over to the new language.

 

Three novel research aspects were reported on in this project: effects of native language on word formation processes in particular, implicit learning of an artificial language with templatic morphology, and language processing in Maltese speakers. Prior studies have investigated the effects of native language word order and sound systems in learning new languages, but not the effects of different systems of word formation. Further, studies that have investigated the learning of artificial languages have not previously focused on templatic morphology: while templatic morphology is rare throughout the world's languages, we still do not have a complete or accurate picture of how languages are processed in general until we are also able to account for languages that do not follow the patterns typical of English and other well-studied European languages. Finally, Maltese itself is an understudied language, despite having official status in the EU and the islands of Malta historically being a main trade port for Africa, the Middle East, and Europe. The more research that is done on understudied languages, the more we know about our language faculty in general, especially with regard to languages' sociocultural and psychological influences on communities.

 

This grant has resulted in four conference presentations, five colloquia or guest lectures, one Ph.D. dissertation, and three publications, including one conference proceedings paper, one journal article under review, and another manuscript in preparation. The products from this grant have also resulted in further collaborations in the US, Canada, England, Germany, Malta, and Slovakia, and have been the basis for several postdoctoral grants at institutions in the US, Canada, England (all in preparation), and Israel (awarded). This grant has also provided employment and valuable research experience for one female undergraduate student, who was involved in many aspects of the project. More broadly, the Co-PI has been involved in discussions with instructors of English (for Arabic speakers) and Arabic (for English speakers) courses about learning mechanisms and designing effective teaching materials that draw on the results from this research. Just by nature of the research process, the importance of the research and of speaking minority languages was also presented to every participant when they had completed the experiments as part of the debriefing session.
